title: Synthetic Recap
body:
**Knicks Survive Pistons in Defensive War as Houston's Heroics Steal the Show**

NEW YORK – In a Eastern Conference battle that was more trench warfare than basketball, the New York Knicks grinded out an 83-78 victory over the Detroit Pistons on the back of a breathtaking individual performance. On a night where points were a precious commodity, Allan Houston authored a masterpiece, pouring in a game-high 33 points to lift his team to victory.

The game was a brutal, defensive slugfest characteristic of the era, with neither team cracking 85 points. But amidst the clanging iron and physical struggles, Houston was a portrait of offensive elegance. The smooth-shooting guard was relentless, slicing through the Detroit defense and hitting from mid-range with a scorer's touch that seemed alien to the contest. While his teammates labored to find any offensive consistency, Houston was the lone beacon, single-handedly keeping the Knicks afloat through multiple scoring droughts.

Detroit, led by Grant Hill's 22 points, hung around with trademark grit. They clawed, they defended, and they made every possession a fight, but they had no answer for Houston’s hot hand. Every time the Pistons threatened to seize momentum, Houston had a response—a silky jumper, a driving layup, a cold-blooded basket to silence the run.

The Knicks ultimately prevailed, but this was not a story of a team victory. This was the story of one man’s transcendent talent rising above the fray. In a game defined by its defensive struggle, Allan Houston didn't just score; he performed, carrying the Knicks on his back and providing a stunning offensive spectacle that those in attendance would not soon forget.
